newsitem.title: USA: GOLF-PRICE RETAINS ONE-STROKE LEAD AFTER SECOND ROUND.
newsitem.headline: GOLF-PRICE RETAINS ONE-STROKE LEAD AFTER SECOND ROUND.

text.p: Nick Price, continuing his return to the form that made him the world's best golfer not so long ago, retained his one-stroke lead after the second round of the Heritage Classic on Friday.

Despite bogeying the final two holes on the most exposed part of the Harbour Town course, Price managed a two-under-par 69 in extremely windy, unseasonally cool conditions on a day when the field averaged 73.1 strokes.
Price, who led by one stroke after the first round, stood at eight-under 134 to keep his slim margin over Lennie Clements, who shot 68, and Brad Faxon and Rick Fehr, who each matched the leader's 69.

"I am really happy with the way I played today, because when it is cold it is hard to feel your grip," said Price, who was ranked number one in the world after winning two major championships in 1994.
"With the exception of the bogeys on 17 and 18, I played almost as well as I could," he said.

"The last five, six tournaments I have been striking the ball very well. The difference this week is that I have finished it off. The greens are so pure. I've got a good feel for them and my pace has been good."
The 39-year-old from Zimbabwe won his first major at the 1992 PGA Championship. In 1994 he won it again, as well as the British Open, but suffered something of a decline over the following two years.
Price says he is striking the ball even better now than three years ago, although the same can't be said of his short game.
"From tee-to-green I probably have more control than ever. My swing is more repetitive," he said. "For the better part of 14, 15 months, my putting wasn't very good."
Price demonstrated that he was on the way back with a pair of victories in South Africa in February.
He stands 16th on this year's PGA Tour money list, despite playing just a handful of events, and has risen to ninth in the world rankings.
While Price tamed the ocean winds, however, many big-name players were blown away.

Among those to miss the cut, which fell at four-over 146, was Briton Nick Faldo, who failed to bounce back from his Masters misery, shooting a four-over 75 Friday for a 149 total. It marked the first time the three-time Masters champion had missed two successive cuts on the PGA Tour since the 1994 Memorial and U.S. Open.
"It's very frustrating. I love this course," said Faldo, who will take three weeks off before returning for the Byron Nelson Classic.
